awd_titl_txt: CAREER: System Theoretic Methods for Understanding the Dynamics of Cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Award (CAREER) project is aimed at understanding cognitive functions in the human brain by investigating neural mechanisms of cognition using tools from systems and control theory. The research will develop mathematical models that will help understand internal brain dynamics. The study will focus on establishing connections between properties of neural circuits and their information processing functionality.  The research will use brain activity data from human subjects to validate the newly developed mathematical models to establish connections between brain dynamics and cognitive functions.  The outcomes of this project can provide insights into developing treatments for neurological conditions associated with altered cognitive functions such as loss of cognitive ability due to severe brain injuries. The project will also help to educate scientists working in the cross-cutting discipline of systems theory and neuroscience and will improve interpretability and accessibility of neurological diagnostics.  The PI has well integrated educational outreach program for students from a St. Louis magnet school that includes use of neurotechnology kits for exploring and visualizing brain dynamics.  This research will foster sustained excitement for scientific inquiry in mathematics and brain science. 

This CAREER project will develop tools and techniques to understand certain cognitive states using methods of dynamics and control theory to analyze the dynamic behavior of neurons and the networks they form. The research will shed light on the role of dynamics and control within micro-scale neuronal networks as they relate to information processing. It will help understand how the dynamics of brain networks enable cognitively salient operations such as multi-modal integration and information retention.  Along with these control-theoretic developments, this work will explore new methods for model- and data-driven characterization of neuronal dynamics at multiple spatial scales. The three specific objectives of this work are: (i) analyzing the relationship between macro-scale brain dynamics and cognitive function through new developments in dynamics and control; (ii) studying how neural dynamics may emerge in ways that support information processing; (iii) ensuring the long-term success of the program through numerous pedagogical and curricular endeavors.

por.por_cntn:
In engineering, it is common to use mathematical models to understand the behavior of physical systems. These models can provide information regarding how these systems work, and in turn how to interact with and manipulate them. For example, we can use equations of motion to predict how a car might response to certain forces, thus helping in the design of its engine. This project adopted this framework in the context of studying not an engineered system, but one that is even more complex: the brain. Understanding how the human brain sustains cognition is a wide-ranging and long-standing question in neuroscience. Mathematical models have the potential to shed light on this question by helping scientists and engineers understand how circuits and networks in the brain transmit and process information. Furthermore, as technologies for recording and manipulating brain circuits continue to develop, building an understanding of how information is transmitted and processed in brain networks is a precursor to eventual translational applications such as restoration of cognitive function through neurostimulation. In the pursuit of these goals, this project yielded several research outcomes. First, it led to the development of new, large-scale models of brain networks, able to capture and describe the interaction of hundreds of brain areas. Second, the research yielded new engineering theory and design methods to enable the use of emerging brain stimulation technologies, which may allow practitioners to more precisely stimulate brain networks. Lastly, the research provided new scientific hypotheses regarding how cells in the brain interact with each other, in order to implement key cognitive functions, such as short-term memory. In the process of achieving these outcomes, the project achieved several broader impacts. Specifically, it facilitated the training of students at graduate and undergraduate levels. Emphasis was placed on interdisciplinary training at the intersection of engineering and neuroscience. The project also enabled K-12 students to participate in research through the development of a neurotechnology kit, which allowed these students to measure and visualize their own brain activity. All research and training outcomes were disseminated broadly through publications and presentations at national research conferences.
